comments.body:
The only odd behavior I can create is if I set 'collections_paths = :'  (an empty list)

``` ini
[defaults]
collections_paths = :
```

In that case, the collection ends up getting installed into $PWD/ansible_collections/.
But I suspect that is a general issue with config types of 'pathspec' and not specific
to collection_path.
Yeah, this should probably be an error if the config has explicitly removed the paths...

comments.body:
This PR increases the complexity of `execute_list` a lot:

devel:
```
galaxy.py:958:4: GalaxyCLI.execute_list (complexity 13)
```

This PR:
```
galaxy.py:976:4: GalaxyCLI.execute_list (complexity 31)
```

I'd recommend breaking this method up into a method for each "type". As it is, I feel like it makes it difficult to review.
I agree, it's really bloated now. Now that I have it working, I'll simplify it.

I have replaced `execute_list()` with two separate methods and moved the nested methods to private class methods. Things are looking much better now.
```
galaxy.py:1035:4: GalaxyCLI.execute_role_list (complexity 9)
galaxy.py:1077:4: GalaxyCLI.execute_collection_list (complexity 9)
```

comments.body: Changing the default paths here is problematic because `collections_path` is also used by `execute_install`. We probably need to add these additional paths only in `execute_list_collection` and possible `execute_verify` if we want to be able to verify collections inside `site-packages` as well.

Update for those following the PR comments: After some discussion in slack: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/70147#issuecomment-646712442

So we do want it to apply to list and verify.  We want it to apply to install when install is checking whether things are already installed but do not want it to apply as a location that can be installed to.  We need to check the implementation to see if we can get away with setting the default here and letting the code sort it out or if we need to use a sentinel for the default and set it to AnsibleCollectionConfig.colection_paths as a default later in the code.

After today's meeting, the above is the long term plan.  But for 2.10, we're going to apply site-packages to list and verify but not install.

I've now looked at the code more closely and `-p`/`--collection-path` is implemented separately for install vs list and verify.  This PR changes the list and verify `--collection-path` but not the install `--collection-path` so it should be ready to go.

```
[pts/146@peru /srv/ansible/abadger8]$ ansible-galaxy collection list community.crypto   
[WARNING]: You are running the development version of Ansible. You should only run Ansible from "devel" if you are
modifying the Ansible engine, or trying out features under development. This is a rapidly changing source of code
and can become unstable at any point.

# /home/badger/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ansible_collections
Collection       Version
---------------- -------
community.crypto 0.1.0  
[pts/146@peru /srv/ansible/abadger8]$ ansible-galaxy collection verify community.crypto
[WARNING]: You are running the development version of Ansible. You should only run Ansible from "devel" if you are
modifying the Ansible engine, or trying out features under development. This is a rapidly changing source of code
and can become unstable at any point.
[pts/146@peru /srv/ansible/abadger8]$ echo $?                           *[collection-list-site-packages]  (10:40:20)
0
[pts/146@peru /srv/ansible/abadger8]$ ansible-galaxy collection install  community.crypto
[WARNING]: You are running the development version of Ansible. You should only run Ansible from "devel" if you are
modifying the Ansible engine, or trying out features under development. This is a rapidly changing source of code
and can become unstable at any point.
Starting galaxy collection install process
Process install dependency map
Starting collection install process
Installing 'community.crypto:0.1.0' to '/home/badger/.ansible/collections/ansible_collections/community/crypto'
```
I tested this out and it works as expected.

comments.body: Could anybody explain why this works/necessary? I think it deserves a code comment. It looks to me like it exploits some side-effect of changing the list in-place instead of reassigning the object but I don't get why this fixes the bug.

I believe it is due to mutating the `dirs` created by `os.walk`, which impacts future iterations that include that same `dirs` reference.

I'm sure we could refactor the code, to not require it, but this is a known good change that works.
After looking at the PR description, it sounds like it'd be saner to use a different variable name. Also, it looks like this could be moved closer to the loop that iterates over these dirs.
I think that's the point, it needs to mutate the existing reference, or the code needs refactored in a larger scale.
